awd_titl_txt: Fluid Dynamics Experiments on Core Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary structure of Earth's interior -- the dense iron-rich metallic core surrounded by the less dense silicate and oxide mantle -- was established during planetary accretion, when the vast amounts of energy released by large impacts produced widespread melting, allowing the denser metals to segregate from the molten silicates and form the core. The purpose of this research is to quantify the fluid mechanical processes by which the core-forming metals partially mixed with and later segregated from the mantle-forming silicates in the early Earth.  

A series of laboratory fluid dynamical experiments will be made using silicone oils and sucrose solutions to model the molten silicates and liquid gallium and other dense fluids to model the core-forming metals in a magma ocean. The experiments will measure the turbulent exchange of heat and chemical tracers between the two fluids under gravitationally stable and unstable conditions, respectively. Important outcomes of this research are experimentally calibrated laws for turbulent heat and chemical exchange between liquid metals and non-metals. We intend to extrapolate our experimental results to the conditions of the early Earth, thereby placing constraints on the initial state of the deep interior, including the initial partitioning of heat and chemical species between the core and the mantle.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project has been to understand how Earth's metallic core formed, how it acquired its high temperature, and what started the geomagnetic field. All of these events occurred within the first billion years of  Earth history, yet they were pivotal in determining how our planet has evolved since that time. 

Geophysical and geochemical observations clearly imply that Earth formed by accretion of planetary embryos, small versions of the terrestrial planets that had already differentiated into a rocky mantle and metallic core. Prodigious amounts of energy were released as these objects collided with the proto-Earth, melting large portions of both target and impactor. This impact-generated molten state defines the starting point for our study, which seeks answers to what happened to the core in the hours, days, and years that followed. 

The originality of our approach has been to develop scale models of the post-impact process, selecting analog fluids for Earth's metal (mostly iron) and magma (molten rock) components using the principles of dimensional analysis as our guide. Through trial-and-error we found that low density silicone oil and higher density solutions of various salts in water are excellent analogs for this purpose, especially because they are immiscible, like magma and molten iron. 

A key issue during core formation is whether the entire column of the mantle melted below the impact point, or just a portion, outcomes that distinguish giant impacts from smaller ones. Our experiments modeled both situations. A typical experimental  is shown in Figure 1. A volume of liquid representing the impactor core is released into another liquid, representing magma. In the case of (relatively) small impacts, which this experiment simulates, the impactor core descends a distance equal to just a few of its diameters before turbulently mixing with the magma. Shortly thereafter it fragments into sub-centimeter drops of iron rain which then accumulate at the base of the magma before sinking en-masse to the core. Turbulent mixing and fragmentation explains a long-standing observation, namely, that partial chemical equilibration between magma and metals occurred deep inside the Earth during accretion.

In the case of giant impacts, where the entire mantle column melts, it has been argued that the impactor core simply merges with the proto-Earth core without entirely fragmenting. Figure 2 shows two experiments that simulate this situation. The impacting core acts like a turbulent projectile in this case, penetrating deep into the proto-Earth core, carrying fragments of magma with it. Eventually the components of this turbulent mixture separate, the magma drops sedimenting upward while the impacting metal mixes with the proto-core. If the impacting core is slightly enriched in lighter elements relative to  Earth's proto-core, as proposed for the moon-forming giant impact, our experiments show that the turbulent mixture collapses back onto the core boundary, producing a lower density, stratified layer at the top of the proto-core in its aftermath. This result is significant, as it offers an explanation for the origin of the stratification  at the top of the present-day core that has been imaged by seismic waves. 

Not all of Earth's metallic core formed during accretion. Petrologic evidence indicates that a small fraction likely formed later, as drops of iron were expelled from the crystallizing magma. We have devised experiments to determine if this expelled iron could be responsible for initiating the geomagnetic field.
